comments.commentBody:
and Elke
John - you can come up for AIR.

We don't even need to make "for profit" colleges illegal. We just need to invest in public institutions - K-12, community colleges and state universities - making sure that there are good paths to college as well as vocational schools to train students for crafts like welding, construction, auto mechanics, electrical work and plumbing. Make state and community colleges free or low-cost, as was the case in the 1960s and 70s.
The same tax money that is being wasted on profits going into the pockets of 1-percenter shareholders in the for-profit 'education industry', would be better spent directly building our state institutions. This is not just fair; it is also good economics. Students who have an easier path to graduation with fewer financial obstacles will graduate in greater numbers and enter the workforce with better skills, in higher-paying jobs. When they finish, they will not be burdened with loans, nor will they be paying a huge percentage of their income to send their own children to college. They will therefore be able to save more for retirement and participate in the economy more. Being better-off, they will pay more taxes and buy more cars, houses, vacations and everything else that makes our economy grow.

I didn't make up the 87% statistic; this has been studied as you can see for yourself through simple online searches. In spite of the truth that automation is really driving the vast majority of manufacturing job loss, many Americans think that free trade agreements are the main driver, and both Trump and Clinton are at fault as well. Finding an economist that thinks that enacting more trade barriers will significantly increase U.S. employment is like finding a climate scientist who thinks global warming is a hoax; you can find them, but they're few and far between.

As a case in point, Foxconn, the company which assembles the iPhone in China, just reduced its Chinese work force by 60,000 due to automation. If cheap Chinese labor can't compete with robots, then, yes, I will tell you that the vast majority of manufacturing jobs in New York and elsewhere were lost to automation, not to free trade agreements. And it is going to get worse, not better. Just wait until autonomous vehicles eliminate 5 million truck, taxi, and Uber jobs.

Nice to see the show runners trying something new with an idyllic, pastoral society headed by a charismatic leader who keeps secrets.  Does Ezekial keep a room full of walker heads in fish tanks, too?
So IOW, useless to poisoning Negan et. all.

I got the impression they didn't really think the pigs would poison the Saviors, just that it was a passive aggressive act, a bit of 'revenge' to have the pigs eat 'rot.'
On the other hand, it's not a bad plan. Could it be foreshadowing? Could Alexandrians find a way to poison their offerings so that it takes out or disables enough saviors that they can dismantle Negan's group?

in Asia during ancient times, pigs were prized as a necessity of the home due to their ability to eat "toxic substances" (such as urine and feces, as well as other discarded items) and produce meat that was untainted.

I think William could be the MIB.

Maybe I am just remembering it incorrectly, but we don't actually know that MIB raped Dolores in the first episode, do we? We just see him drag her into the barn.

Is it possible that he is William and because we are seeing the narrative from Teddy's POV at that moment that's what we are led to believe? Maybe once in the barn something more significant happens. She certainly flashes back to something having happened in the barn later on when she runs in there on her 'loop', but at the time I think we are supposed to assume it is a rape.

The other thing I have begun to suspect is that Logan and young Will are hosts. I think that Ford might have planted them there deliberately to see if Delores really does know anything about Arnold (if she has communicated with him etc) Because I think she knew the MIB/William in his YOUNGER days. I suspect she may even have been *based* on his fiancée- Logan's sister. And the only reason that William or Logan has not been killed is because the other hosts are programmed not to - with the updates Ford has given them.

This would explain why Dolores can report back each night whilst in their company and why William suddenly seemed to go on 'autopilot' when shooting the union men. It was like he was programmed to do it.

In this respect, I fully expect the MIB to not be a villain.

All of mankind desires the blessings of an industrial society, including cars with engines, dependable access to electricity, safe food storage, and access to air conditioning for their home.

Capitalism allows the developing world to have these things without the cruelty of elites demanding that people simply do without. The antic, frantic left not only can't deal with more ice accumulating at the earth's poles but the new ways capitalist inventors deal with basic needs.

Leftist collectivism and unthinking environmental scare stories will always fail in the marketplace of ideas and free speech because each man and woman wants to improve their life more that lining up for a socialist feel-good dogma.

India will handle its needs for modern things just fine without the all-thumbs buffoons of progressivism making another mockery of things.
Your comment makes a great deal of sense!

"Free trade" has been an oxymoron: for economists, they implied a huge increase in imports from China and other 'emerging' economies and ignored the rock-solid protectionism on the Chinese, Indian etc sides which aimed to get as much of Western know-how for free.

Who benefited from this? China and Western 1% centers. Who has been a major loser? The middle classes in Europe and US. If globalism is to become a positive factor it has to emerge from new rules that better serve the West.
People will always buy the cheapest.  Your idealism is unrealistic and will lead to the wrong decision.

If it's free it's not trade & if it's trade it's not free.

There is a vast cost to corporate imports of cheap, disposable consumerist goods.

It is far more rewarding to support & sustain local sustainable artisans & farmers for goods wherever possible.

Trade would be acceptable if it's Fair Trade. But Fair Trade is so underrepresented it barely exists.

Cut out the corporatist big-box retailers & support independent artisans. Encourage independent production before industrial manufacturing wherever possible, continue to celebrate reclaimed, reused, repurposed materials wherever possible.

Demand a verifiable Sustainably Produced label on all domestically manufactured goods, and a verifiable Sustainably Produced Fair Trade label for all imported goods.

If production is outsourced it must require a living wage & workplace standards, or we should boycott the goods & services from corporations that exploit.

Asia has been on the winning side in all trade. Like domestic companies growth is affected by many factors and their growth has been with a mindset that it would never end or go down. Any business or company that builds thinking everything is going up forever is in for a ride awakening.
Many US industries had to rethink. Entertainment, telecom, retail, airlines and on and on.

I have always believed that much of the current malaise can be laid upon the steps of the Harvard Business School with their slavish worship of quarterly profits.

Here is just one example: Toyota wanted to enter the upscale/luxury car market, and did so in 1989 with their separately branded Lexus car line which was sold in a different chain of dealerships.

Their original offering was a four door sedan (the 400 series) which had over 100 new patents incorporated in its design, but sold in the high 30's when the comparable 500 Class Mercedes went for $85.000.

Did Toyota make money on those highly sophisticated cars back then?
I am certain those were "loss leaders" like $2.00 anti-freeze to generate sales. It worked and soon the Lexus dealerships' used car sections were packed with Benzes and Beemers.

Which brings me back to my point that worshiping at the alter of quarterly profits is short term thinking at a point in history that the long view is the better way to see things.

Think back to the years when the North American Free Trade Agreement heralded a ramped up exodus of manufacturing. Do you recall all the attempts at marketing "Global Investing"? That money was used to build the foreign factories that took American workers jobs whose pension money was used to build the factories that took their jobs.

Globalization and "Global Investing" is a Wall Street endeavor we have all come to resent.

Remember the "Occupy Wall Street" demonstrations? They were right.

Remember that the NYPD sided with big money, as they always do, and abused those demonstrators who made sacrifices in the national interest, something Wall Street did not.

It wasn't entirely the fault of Corporate executives for abandoning America. It was instigated by Wall Street who commanded extraordinary cost cutting to maximize stock values and dividends.

Trump need look no further than his own Manhattan Island to effect change.
That's what we do in America. They are called prisons. The difference is that here they are put in boxes so we don't have to see them. And you all know who "them" are.
Especially confounding considering the limits and restrictions the Chinese place on other country who host Pandas.
Please release the polar bear. He will be very happy when he will get freedom. Animals are loving and polite. He wants freedom that's all and we can see in the video.please don't hurt  his feelings.
"Until you change the way money works, you change nothing" M. C. Ruppert.
Some people are really aware that all form of life is valuable and beautiful and needs respect.

How can this be allowed? Please can we get together and save this polar bear, the CHINESE have taken our Tigers, our Rhinos and use Elephant tusks...what for? They boil cats alive, skin dogs alive .....time we stopped this NOW!

We worked with Inner Mongolian herders for 4 years to create a sustainable supply chain for cashmere and camel fiber. We learned that herders know how to manage the fragile eco-system. Sadly, the Chinese government, and some national and international NGOs, argued that "exclosures" fencing out herders and animals, would stabilize the desert. There is indeed often a sudden dramatic increase in biomass when no animals graze. However, when drought occurs, the unpruned/overgrown plants cannot survive-too much energy into top growth,not root growth. Any long term solution requires a delicate balance of land, carrying capacity and grazing animal pruning. We found a combination of goats and camels was most sustainable.
Our experience with declining water tables- they were caused as much or more by mining than climate change. Trees that had survived for centuries, and were sacred sites, were dying because deep open pit mines pump out massive amounts of water, which is now polluted and runs across the surface of the desert adding to herder problems.
We found some wonderful people working on the preservation of herder sustainable grazing practices and herder culture, both of which hold the solution for stabilizing deserts in Ningxia. They are fighting an uphill battle and sadly climate change is adding to the challenges: 1) it objectively aggravates desertification, 2) it provides a too rarely challenged excuse for forced relocation of indigenous, largely Muslim, people.

They'll have to pay market price for commestibles, but shipping water is impractical...absent a sharp volte-face, 6.8 of 7.5 BN today [later 9.2 of 10.3 BN] could perish before 2100 CE...tax carbon heavily [say, $75-100 per ton] or expect ecollapse-at-scale...little time remains to curtail greenhouse gases [incl. hydrates & clathrates]...runaway to 6-degree-Celsius rise in mean planetary temps is probably unstoppable...there are no miracles in the natural world...sarbat da bhala.
This is an important article/interview from both environmental and humanitarian perspectives.
Herders are the antithesis of what the Chinese Politburo considers the 'ideal citizen', not surprising they're being moved for any and all reasons.

See nothing that justifies your optimism; 20 top climos [incl. Hansen] admit that stopping at 4-Celsius might save 2 billion lives, depending upon monsoons [5 of which seem to be weakening]...but not even hardiest scrub [30-degrees N. Latitude to 30 South] can survive prolonged 130-F noonday temps...Australia is likely uninhabitable-at-scale...at 5-C, ravening ecogees might flee toward polar Canada, Norway & Siberia, but soils there are waterlogged & growing seasons are short...planetary ecollapse might again leave us w/600-1000 fertile couples [as post-Mt. Toba 72 KYA]...however, surface minerals were depleted by 1920 CE, so civilization could not be rebuilt--Colonia Martialis thus rendered nugatory.

The overriding story here is the expansion of the deserts. It is projected that unless global warming is reversed, by the time the earth increases 4 degrees centigrade, expected by 2100, neither China or India the most populist nations in the world will be inhabitable. Those left alive will inhabit the arctic and in America along Canadian boarder and above. No one is ready for that discussion, but it appears it is coming. Think about what ‘government policy’ may look like in the interim.
Anthropologists see a basic difference in social structure between farmers and herders, farming requires cooperative agreements primarily in water utilization and thus community centered decision making. Herders look to the earth as an endless grass field not needing social interaction thus are much more independent in attitude and life style. For bureaucrats the latter are problematic, but neither will survive global warming.
